messages.text:
The world wide number new cases per day (which is proportional to rate of new cases) is at an all time high if you take a 7 day moving average, at about 600k new cases per day.
And the places where it has levelled off align to either large scale lockdowns, or the northern hemisphere summer
<https://www.worldometers.info/coronavirus/?utm_campaign=homeAdvegas1>?

(Remember a linear number of new cases implies a quadratic number of active cases)

messages.text: I kind of doubt that it is mutations to the virus, making it become less virulent, because I keep hearing that scientists are tracking the genetic sequences, and while one variant (that possibly is more contagious, but not any more deadly) seems to have replaced the original virus that came out of Wuhan, and another (found in the minks in Denmark) might be more, not less, virulent.  I think we’d have heard some evidence by now if there any of those trends had been caused by less deadly mutations.

elements.text: I kind of doubt that it is mutations to the virus, making it become less virulent, because I keep hearing that scientists are tracking the genetic sequences, and while one variant (that possibly is more contagious, but not any more deadly) seems to have replaced the original virus that came out of Wuhan, and another (found in the minks in Denmark) might be more, not less, virulent.  I think we’d have heard some evidence by now if there any of those trends had been caused by less deadly mutations.

messages.text: sure but there are ~1000 mutations not just a handful and we still don't have certainty about the virulence of the 'original' covid

messages.text:
I work with genetics in a flu lab with the corona-guys sitting in the next door office. I strongly suspect it's been getting less virulent over time, but there is no way we can prove it, since we have mediocre estimates of infection fatality ratio, and we have very poor estimates of it when we factor in the changing treatment over time and other confounding factors. So it's just an unsupported hypothesis at this time.
The mink ones were probably not more virulent either, the problem was that it was an immune escape mutant which could make the vaccine less efficient

elements.text:
I work with genetics in a flu lab with the corona-guys sitting in the next door office. I strongly suspect it's been getting less virulent over time, but there is no way we can prove it, since we have mediocre estimates of infection fatality ratio, and we have very poor estimates of it when we factor in the changing treatment over time and other confounding factors. So it's just an unsupported hypothesis at this time.
The mink ones were probably not more virulent either, the problem was that it was an immune escape mutant which could make the vaccine less efficient

messages.text:
This is true over long timescales, it's unclear how much selective pressure there is going to be on a brand new spillover in this short a period of time.

Also, the typical logic is that sick people are less mobile / less likely to spread, but for a virus where a lot of the infectious window appears to be asymptomatic, this pressure will be even lower.

All of this is to say that I haven't seen any evidence that there are substantive changes in virulence or transmissibility due to viral evolution (there were a couple of papers about one strain a while back, but their evidence was weak IMO). That said, I also wouldn't rule out the possibility that it *could* be happening and we just don't have sufficient evidence yet.

root.text: I have heard that in general that there is (relatively fast acting)  evolutionary pressure on viruses to be become less deadly, because dead people spread no virus, so mutations that leave people alive favoured to speed more

elements.text: I have heard that in general that there is (relatively fast acting)  evolutionary pressure on viruses to be become less deadly, because dead people spread no virus, so mutations that leave people alive favoured to speed more

This is true over long timescales, it's unclear how much selective pressure there is going to be on a brand new spillover in this short a period of time.

Also, the typical logic is that sick people are less mobile / less likely to spread, but for a virus where a lot of the infectious window appears to be asymptomatic, this pressure will be even lower.

All of this is to say that I haven't seen any evidence that there are substantive changes in virulence or transmissibility due to viral evolution (there were a couple of papers about one strain a while back, but their evidence was weak IMO). That said, I also wouldn't rule out the possibility that it
could
be happening and we just don't have sufficient evidence yet.

messages.text:
This is really far from a worst-case scenario - honestly in terms of things with pandemic potential, this was sort of best-case, since it's sufficiently bad to spur a different response than annual influenza, but not so bad that we're likely to reach hundreds of millions dead.

We might actually be better prepared for the next one

messages.text:
Here’s an interesting article where my country comes on top in a good way. It’s probably true what they say in this, but Finland’s response has been nowhere near perfect. For example the question of masks has been controversial; in spring the health authorities commissioned a study that concluded that face masks are not useful. In fall they started saying that face masks are useful in crowded situations, and recently they suggest their use in shops and transportation. Face masks are not mandatory, and maybe 60%-80% use them based on my own observations. This weekend there was a lot of shopping going on in person, and I fear that will not go well with the virus, but we’ll see.
One thing I’d like to point out is that the compensation for lost income the article states is not just for the pandemic, it’s the normal state of affairs. You get sick, you stay home, you get most of the income anyway. I understand that in the US you mostly don’t get that compensation, so sick people are incentivised to stay at work when they’re slightly sick and infect others. I was myself tested once for covid-19, and it cost me zero euros; I got the time for the appointment for the test for the next day, and I got results in two days after that (negative), so our healthcare is also making it a lot easier to get tested.
<https://edition.cnn.com/2020/12/20/europe/europe-covid-restrictions/index.html>

attachments.title: Europe's coronavirus crisis is resurging. For months, 3 Nordic nations kept it under control — without lockdowns
attachments.text: Denmark, Finland and Norway kept Covid-19 death rates low for months, despite some of Europe's most relaxed restrictions, a CNN analysis has found.
attachments.fallback: CNN: Europe's coronavirus crisis is resurging. For months, 3 Nordic nations kept it under control — without lockdowns

elements.text:
Here’s an interesting article where my country comes on top in a good way. It’s probably true what they say in this, but Finland’s response has been nowhere near perfect. For example the question of masks has been controversial; in spring the health authorities commissioned a study that concluded that face masks are not useful. In fall they started saying that face masks are useful in crowded situations, and recently they suggest their use in shops and transportation. Face masks are not mandatory, and maybe 60%-80% use them based on my own observations. This weekend there was a lot of shopping going on in person, and I fear that will not go well with the virus, but we’ll see.
One thing I’d like to point out is that the compensation for lost income the article states is not just for the pandemic, it’s the normal state of affairs. You get sick, you stay home, you get most of the income anyway. I understand that in the US you mostly don’t get that compensation, so sick people are incentivised to stay at work when they’re slightly sick and infect others. I was myself tested once for covid-19, and it cost me zero euros; I got the time for the appointment for the test for the next day, and I got results in two days after that (negative), so our healthcare is also making it a lot easier to get tested.

messages.text: infection in the first wave was significantly lower than second wave so i doubt it covered all the weakest individuals. if it is true, the spread of infection follows the small-world network where there are small super-spreaders which can infect a lot of people in its immediate neighborhood. small-world network will just need two to three hops to reach these vulnerable ones like in social networks.

messages.text:
:joy:
Man travels  4.5 hours via  jetski from Scottland t the Isle of Man, then walks 25km to see his girlfriend.
He is thrown in jail 2 days later for covid breach, as the Isle of Man is closed to non-residents.
He was in jail for 2 weeks, before being send back to the mainland. (let out early, was meant to be 4)
<https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-isle-of-man-55428761>

attachments.title: Covid breach jet-skier freed from Isle of Man jail
attachments.text: Dale McLaughlan says he is "happy to be going home" after part of his sentence on the Isle of Man.
attachments.fallback: BBC News: Covid breach jet-skier freed from Isle of Man jail

messages.text:
With the recent outbreak in Sydney, some of my friends in Western Australia are like “We need the vaccine”.
I think if you run the numbers, you are vastly more likely to get covid after being vaccinated in the US or UK, than you are as a unvaccinated person in Western Australia.

elements.text:

I think if you run the numbers, you are vastly more likely to get covid after being vaccinated in the US or UK, than you are as a unvaccinated person in Western Australia.

messages.text: I worry that there are so many anti-vaxxers here in the US, plus the people who don’t trust it because Trump was pressuring people to have the vaccines approved before the election (including my wife, I’m sad to say), that we won’t be able to achieve herd immunity, to protect the people who really can’t take the vaccine for medical reasons, or for the 5% where it’s wasn’t effective.

messages.text: I wonder what happens if you get sars-cov-2 a week after your first shot of the Pfizer vaccine, but before the second.

messages.text: <https://berthub.eu/articles/posts/reverse-engineering-source-code-of-the-biontech-pfizer-vaccine/>

attachments.title: Reverse Engineering the source code of the BioNTech/Pfizer SARS-CoV-2 Vaccine - Articles
attachments.text: Welcome! In this post, we’ll be taking a character-by-character look at the source code of the BioNTech/Pfizer SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccine. I want to thank the large cast of people who spent time previewing this article for legibility and correctness. All mistakes remain mine though, but I would love to hear about them quickly at <mailto:bert@hubertnet.nl|bert@hubertnet.nl> or @PowerDNS_Bert Now, these words may be somewhat jarring - the vaccine is a liquid that gets injected in your arm.
attachments.fallback: Articles: Reverse Engineering the source code of the BioNTech/Pfizer SARS-CoV-2 Vaccine - Articles

messages.text: How exactly is it know that it has a higher infection rate? Also, I heard that some even newer variant came to UK from South Africa, with an even higher rate than that. (It was in some news.)

elements.text: How exactly is it know that it has a higher infection rate? Also, I heard that some even newer variant came to UK from South Africa, with an even higher rate than that. (It was in some news.)

messages.text:
I don’t think we are even 100% sure it has a higher infection rate.
We think it does, but are not sure because of the Bayesian prior (is that right) isn’t known.
And we have been fooled before where a strain was thought to be more contagious but it wasn’t, it was just that transmission was high in a region general at by chance that strain was what was in that area

Supporting evidence though is that it has a couple of mutations that are believed to cause higher transmissability. (I think, but am not sure, that 1 of them had a actual expermental study done on lab cultures)
those mutations are shared with the South African one.

messages.text: i think high incidence of particular variant somehow indicates high infection rate. also, they can perhaps sequence and check what part in the sequence mutated and possible effect in the phenotype. of course i’m just brainstorming what likely should be the steps to characterize each variant in terms of infection efficacy or even death efficacy.

elements.text: We did it England. New Record. Well Done.

messages.text: Denmark seem to be completely losing control of the situation. More restrictions were added earlier in December, but the numbers kept rising nevertheless. We now have nearly twice the number of hospitalized as we did at the spring peak, and the Christmas infections hasn't even hit yet. We are about to have the new year's evening parties, which are traditionally drunk and disinhibited, and this with a population already weary of the restrictions. New restrictions will be announced by the prime minister in one hour. Unless restrictions are truly draconian, I expect the situation to completely derail the next two weeks.

elements.text: Denmark seem to be completely losing control of the situation. More restrictions were added earlier in December, but the numbers kept rising nevertheless. We now have nearly twice the number of hospitalized as we did at the spring peak, and the Christmas infections hasn't even hit yet. We are about to have the new year's evening parties, which are traditionally drunk and disinhibited, and this with a population already weary of the restrictions. New restrictions will be announced by the prime minister in one hour. Unless restrictions are truly draconian, I expect the situation to completely derail the next two weeks.

messages.text:
The papers in the UK are talking about a Tier 5.
Even though their is actually no real source on it just some advisor to an advisor to the government saying they thought there needed to be a new level of restrictions.

We had tier 1-3 of restrictions; where still things were open, but e.g. hospitality was increasingly restricted, and number of people you were allowed to meet went down.
then Tier 4 was recently added that was basically the same as the 2nd lockdown rules: stay home, everything non-essential is closed, schools are open, unlimited exercise permitted. Plus strong recommendation for vulnerable people to say at home at all times (which we hadn’t had since first lockdown)
I guess a tier 5 would look a bit more like first lockdown.
Schools closed, excise restricted to 1 session of “reasonable length”, need a good reason to leave your house.

Idk it is hard to see how they can esculate.  Possibly if they do bring in needing a good reason to leave the house then they can bring in enformence of that. Though that didn’t go down well before.

messages.text: It seems like we are past a limit beyond which a large part of society will not attend the government call. Maybe 9 months was that limit. Mexico City keeps opening new hospitals, adding campaign hospitals, adding beds in the parking lots of hospitals, bringing doctors from other states, but numbers keep rising from gatherings, travel, etc… There is just no way to add that many beds.

messages.text: ouch: <https://www.nytimes.com/2020/12/21/world/americas/mexico-city-covid.html>

attachments.title: Mexico Misled Citizens About the Severity of Coronavirus in its Capital
attachments.text: The federal government had data that should have prompted an immediate lockdown in early December. Instead, it kept the city open for another two weeks.
attachments.fallback: The New York Times Mexico Misled Citizens About the Severity of Coronavirus in its Capital

messages.text: That note has been disputed by the government. To be fair this is one of the most transparent and progressive governments we have had in many years, so I remain skeptical of that note even if it is by the NYT. The federal government answers questions from journalists every day and the local one at least once a week, but I have never seen that journalist come to ask questions directly from the people handling the pandemic. The public health system is enormous but it had been abandoned for decades (one of the two main social security institutions had not opened a new hospital in around 20 years and it just did). Fortunately the federal government had been investing in the system the last two years, and I think one of the few things the pandemic will leave is that it is really forcing an even larger investment in our old, long forgotten system.

elements.text: That note has been disputed by the government. To be fair this is one of the most transparent and progressive governments we have had in many years, so I remain skeptical of that note even if it is by the NYT. The federal government answers questions from journalists every day and the local one at least once a week, but I have never seen that journalist come to ask questions directly from the people handling the pandemic. The public health system is enormous but it had been abandoned for decades (one of the two main social security institutions had not opened a new hospital in around 20 years and it just did). Fortunately the federal government had been investing in the system the last two years, and I think one of the few things the pandemic will leave is that it is really forcing an even larger investment in our old, long forgotten system.

attachments.title: New, more contagious COVID-19 variant confirmed in Colorado
attachments.text: Colorado public health officials on Tuesday confirmed the presence of the new variant of COVID-19 first discovered in the U.K., saying the state is the first to identify the strain in the U.S.

messages.text: I’m currently stuck sharing a house with somebody who 1) teaches 3-12 year olds 5 days a week in person 2) goes shopping a few times a week 3) is out with other people Friday night, as well as most of Saturday and Sunday.   I’m really tired now of having to take social distancing precautions *inside* the house (I am at high risk if I get COVID-19, due to age, high blood pressure and Type 2 diabetes).   Now with this new strain, that makes it even more likely that I’ll catch it right here at home, really makes me feel hopeless.

messages.text: I'm quite worried about the increased posting here of articles from "international news" that are pretty much opinion pieces describing the situation and the response made in different countries. This articles often have a conspiracy type of angle and are likely optimized to drive clicks / provide ad revenue by praying on peoples fear and schadenfreude. I think it would be good to try keep posting towards more factual type of articles instead.

elements.text: I'm quite worried about the increased posting here of articles from "international news" that are pretty much opinion pieces describing the situation and the response made in different countries. I think it would be good to try keep posting towards more factual type of articles instead.

messages.text: <https://www.nytimes.com/2020/12/30/world/asia/china-coronavirus.html>

attachments.title: 25 Days That Changed the World: How Covid-19 Slipped China’s Grasp
attachments.text: Beijing acted against the coronavirus with stunning force, as its official narratives recount. But not before a political logjam had allowed a local outbreak to kindle a global pandemic.
attachments.fallback: The New York Times 25 Days That Changed the World: How Covid-19 Slipped China’s Grasp

messages.text:
I am feeling fairly hopeful about the UK's ability to hit 2 million vaccinations/week by end of January.

The 1million in the last month was with about 1 vaccination site for every 6 GP practices.
With the Oxford vaccine because it's so easy to deal with, being it only needs normal fridge and there is no need to observe people for 15minutes after it's going to be much better.
They say they are planning for every GP practice.
Plus pharmacists.
Plus mass vaccination centers (which are due to open 2nd week of January)

According to the defense secretary (so take it with more than a few grains of salt) they have 250 trained teams of military personnel who estimate they can do 100,000 vaccinations per day.

And while I am reading that volunteers are hella frustrated with how hard it is to get certified to be allowed to volunteer, they still have recruited thousands of people.

So while I think it will be a pretty shaky first few weeks, I am hopeful.

elements.text:
I am feeling fairly hopeful about the UK's ability to hit 2 million vaccinations/week by end of January.

The 1million in the last month was with about 1 vaccination site for every 6 GP practices.
With the Oxford vaccine because it's so easy to deal with, being it only needs normal fridge and there is no need to observe people for 15minutes after it's going to be much better.
They say they are planning for every GP practice.
Plus pharmacists.
Plus mass vaccination centers (which are due to open 2nd week of January)

According to the defense secretary (so take it with more than a few grains of salt) they have 250 trained teams of military personnel who estimate they can do 100,000 vaccinations per day.

And while I am reading that volunteers are hella frustrated with how hard it is to get certified to be allowed to volunteer, they still have recruited thousands of people.

So while I think it will be a pretty shaky first few weeks, I am hopeful.
